title: About Amber
description:
Baltic amber has many secrets. It brings to mind positive energy, a good luck charm and a seaside souvenir.
It’s called the Gold of the Baltic and the Living Stone.
It was created by nature: it is a fossilised resin.
Baltic amber’s scent is its unique feature. It smells like pine resin.
Amber is light. You can charge amber so that it attracts lint.
The largest piece of Baltic amber found to date weighs almost 10kg. It is 47 cm in length.
Natural pieces of amber come in different colours and shapes. No two pieces of natural amber are alike.
The way people have different skin colours, amber comes in different colours too. Colour the pieces in shades of yellow, orange, red and brown. You can also leave some white areas.
The colours and colour effects we see are the result of the changes that took place in the resin and of the conditions in which the amber rested underground for millions of years.
Baltic amber does not always have the same colour through and through. You can often find exciting patterns of two or more colours and shades.

Folk dictionaries describe over 100 colours of amber.
Yellow is the most common colour of Baltic amber, associated with the sun.
Unique combinations of two or more colours or shades can occur.
If you look at a text through a polished piece of amber, you can see three effects:
the text can be clearly visible, difficult to see or not visible at all. It all depends on what kind of amber you have.

Baltic amber can be: transparent, translucent or opaque.
The white colour of amber is caused by microscopic gas bubbles sealed inside the resin when it was hardening a long time ago.
The more bubbles there are, the less transparent and lighter the amber is.

Baltic amber can be transparent, translucent, or opaque.
Opacity is due to light reflection and scattering by tiny gas bubbles inside the resin.
Bubbles are 0.0008-0.0010 mm in diameter, trapped during fossilization.
More bubbles result in less transparency.
Over time, colours change, starting from the surface. Amber darkens, becoming noble - more intense and saturated.
